Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a High-Resolution Quadrupole Time-of-Flight Tandem Mass Spectrometer for Advancing Research and Education at the University of Maryland College Park
Award.AbstractNarration: This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. Professor Peter Nemes from the University of Maryland College Park and colleagues Daniel Falvey, Lyle Isaacs, Lisa Taneyhill and Scott Juntti are acquiring a high-resolution, high-pressure liquid chromatograph mass spectrometer with electrospray ionization capabilities (HR-HPLC-ESI-MS). In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species embedded in complex samples. In a typical experiment, the components flow into a mass spectrometer where they are ionized into ions and the ions' masses are measured. This highly sensitive technique allows the structure of molecules in complex mixtures to be studied. An instrument with a liquid chromatograph can separate mixtures of compounds before they reach the mass spectrometer. In the electrospray technique a high voltage is applied to a liquid to create an aerosol. This voltage is useful to produce ions from large molecules by avoiding the propensity of macromolecules to fragment when ionized. The acquisition strengthens the research infrastructure at the University and regional area. The instrument broadens participation by involving diverse groups of students in research and research training using this modern analytical technique. The acquisition also provides training opportunities to many undergraduate and graduate students as well as postdoctoral fellows at this institution. The new capability to measure both small biological and organic molecules in a shared Mass Spectrometry Facility has a broad impact on scientists and students in the District of Columbia-Maryland-Virginia region through workshops as well as curriculum modernization and collaborations with Bowie State University.<br/> <br/><br/>The award of the mass spectrometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It especially impacts studies of metabolic effectors of embryonic development and hormone metabolite activity in nervous system functions. The instrumentation is also used for research on mitochondrial metabolism in the liver as well as molecular mechanisms in neural crest and dental placode cells. In addition, the MS provides information useful for the search of the next generation enzymatic kinetic isotope effects and for studying binders for the valosine-containing protein (VCP) that segregate protein molecules from large cellular structures. The mass spectrometer is also used to inform the design of efficient syntheses for molecular guest compounds. It is also utilized in investigations of electrophilic nitrogen containing species and their reactivity with proteins and nucleic acids.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has provided an integrated Waters ACQUITY I-Class Plus liquid chromatograph (LC) and a Bruker Maxis-II mass spectrometer. The instruments have been delivered, installed, integrated, tested, and validated in a mass spectrometry (MS) facility at the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Maryland, College Park. This facility has been providing analytical and consulting services and supports education activities in MS at the University of Maryland and the greater District of Columbia–Maryland–Virginia community for ~20 years. The microflow liquid chromatograph has enabled high-performance and robust separation of small compounds from synthetic reactions or complex biological systems. The quadrupole time-of-flight tandem mass spectrometer has enabled unequivocal identification of ion signals by recording the accurate mass, fragmentation pattern, and isobaric distribution envelope. A new-generation digitizer has extended the linear dynamic range of quantification. We have leveraged this instrumental resource to enable qualitative (detection and identification) and quantitative (knowledge of amounts, concentrations) analyses in chemistry and biology research projects. We have developed LC-MS approaches to measure small and middle-sized biomolecules (metabolites, hormones, nucleotides, and peptides) with important implications in biological processes (embryogenesis, central and peripheral nervous system development/function, signaling, and mitochondrial function) as well as products of synthetic reactions (e.g., small host-guest complexes and products of photochemistry) with applications in molecular assemblies, catalysis, and energy. To date, this biological mass spectrometer instrument has enhanced research in 40+ groups and 100+ users across 10+ departments at UMD as well as 20+ users in the immediate District of Columbia (DC)-Maryland (MD)-Virginia (VA) area, including the nearby Bowie State University. The new knowledge from these studies has been disseminated in the form of publications and peer-reviewed publications. The new measurement capabilities that have been enabled by the instruments have supported several junior faculty members at UMD, who have successfully established their independent research program with access to these MS resources. The instrument has been incorporated into trainings, workshops, and curriculum modernization and development both at UMD and Bowie State University.
